concepts.concept_name: Measurement of length, mass, and time

in_scope: Physical quantities: fundamental and derived
Fundamental quantities: length, mass, time
SI system of units
Units of length: metre, centimetre, millimetre, kilometre
Units of mass: kilogram, gram, milligram
Units of time: second, minute, hour
Measurement using rulers and metre scales
Measurement using spring balance and physical balance
Reading graduated cylinders for volume
Least count of measuring instruments
out_of_scope: Vernier calipers and screw gauge — Introduced in Class 8
Dimensional analysis — Introduced in Class 9
Significant figures in detail — Introduced in Class 9

in_scope: Rest: object not changing position
Motion: object changing position with time
Reference point or origin
Types of motion: rectilinear, circular, rotational, oscillatory
Distance: total path length
Displacement: shortest distance between two points
Speed: distance covered per unit time
Speed = Distance / Time
SI unit of speed: m/s
Average speed calculation
Uniform and non-uniform motion
Distance-time graphs for uniform motion
Velocity: speed with direction
out_of_scope: Acceleration calculations — Introduced in Class 8
Equations of motion — Introduced in Class 9
Velocity-time graphs — Introduced in Class 8

numeric_limits.speed_values: simple whole numbers or simple decimals

in_scope: Force as push or pull
Effects of force: change in speed, direction, shape
Contact forces: muscular force, friction, normal force
Non-contact forces: gravitational, magnetic, electrostatic
Friction: force opposing motion
Causes of friction: roughness of surfaces
Types of friction: static, sliding, rolling
Advantages and disadvantages of friction
Methods to reduce or increase friction
Balanced forces: no change in motion
Unbalanced forces: cause change in motion
out_of_scope: Force formula F = ma — Introduced in Class 8
Coefficient of friction — Introduced in Class 9
Newton's laws of motion — Introduced in Class 9

in_scope: Thrust: force acting perpendicular to surface
Pressure: force per unit area
Pressure = Force / Area
SI unit of pressure: Pascal (Pa)
Relationship between pressure and area
Pressure in liquids increases with depth
Liquids exert pressure in all directions
Atmospheric pressure: air exerts pressure
Evidence of atmospheric pressure
Applications: knife edge, camel feet, foundation of buildings
Drinking straw, suction cups work due to atmospheric pressure
out_of_scope: Pressure formula P = rho gh in detail — Introduced in Class 8
Pascal's law — Introduced in Class 8
Barometer reading and calculations — Introduced in Class 8

in_scope: Energy: capacity to do work
SI unit of energy: Joule (J)
Forms of energy: kinetic, potential, heat, light, sound, chemical, electrical
Kinetic energy: energy of motion
Potential energy: stored energy due to position
Energy can be transformed from one form to another
Examples of energy transformations in daily life
Law of conservation of energy: energy cannot be created or destroyed
Renewable sources: solar, wind, hydro
Non-renewable sources: coal, petroleum, natural gas
out_of_scope: Energy formulas KE = 1/2 mv^2 and PE = mgh — Introduced in Class 8
Work-energy theorem — Introduced in Class 9
Power calculations — Introduced in Class 8

in_scope: Heat: form of energy that flows from hot to cold body
Temperature: degree of hotness or coldness
Difference between heat and temperature
Thermometer: measuring temperature
Celsius and Fahrenheit scales
Three modes of heat transfer: conduction, convection, radiation
Conduction: heat transfer through solids
Good and bad conductors of heat
Convection: heat transfer through fluids
Convection currents in liquids and gases
Radiation: heat transfer without medium
Applications: cooking utensils, insulation, sea breeze, land breeze
out_of_scope: Heat capacity and specific heat — Introduced in Class 8
Thermal expansion coefficients — Introduced in Class 8
Temperature conversion formulas — Introduced in Class 8

in_scope: Light: form of energy that helps us see
Light travels in straight lines (rectilinear propagation)
Luminous and non-luminous objects
Transparent, translucent, and opaque materials
Reflection: bouncing back of light from a surface
Regular and diffuse (irregular) reflection
Incident ray, reflected ray, normal, angle of incidence, angle of reflection
First law: incident ray, reflected ray, and normal lie in same plane
Second law: angle of incidence = angle of reflection
Plane mirror: flat reflecting surface
Image in plane mirror: virtual, erect, same size, laterally inverted
out_of_scope: Refraction of light — Introduced in Class 8
Curved mirrors — Introduced in Class 8
Multiple reflections — Introduced in Class 8

in_scope: Sound is produced by vibration
Vibrating objects produce sound
Sound requires a medium to travel
Sound cannot travel through vacuum
Sound travels through solids, liquids, and gases
Speed of sound: fastest in solids, slowest in gases
Loudness: related to amplitude of vibration
Pitch: related to frequency of vibration
Quality or timbre: distinguishes sounds of same pitch and loudness
Echo: reflection of sound
Conditions for hearing echo
Noise pollution: harmful effects and prevention
out_of_scope: Wave equations v = f lambda — Introduced in Class 8
Ultrasound and infrasound — Introduced in Class 9
Echo calculations — Introduced in Class 9

in_scope: Electric current: flow of electric charges
Current flows from positive to negative terminal
Electric circuit: closed path for current flow
Components: cell, battery, bulb, switch, wire
Conductors: materials that allow current to flow
Insulators: materials that resist current flow
Examples of conductors and insulators
Heating effect of current: electric heater, bulb
Magnetic effect of current: electromagnet
Chemical effect of current: electroplating (introduction)
Circuit symbols for cell, battery, bulb, switch, wire
Open and closed circuits
out_of_scope: Ohm's law — Introduced in Class 8
Series and parallel circuits in detail — Introduced in Class 8
Electric power and energy calculations — Introduced in Class 9

in_scope: Magnet: object that attracts iron, cobalt, nickel
Natural and artificial magnets
Magnetic and non-magnetic materials
Poles of magnet: North and South
Like poles repel, unlike poles attract
Magnetic field: region around magnet
Magnetic field lines: direction from N to S
Electromagnet: temporary magnet made using current
Making an electromagnet: coil, iron core, current
Factors affecting electromagnet strength
Applications: compass, electric bell, crane, speakers
out_of_scope: Earth's magnetic field in detail — Introduced in Class 8
Electromagnetic induction — Introduced in Class 10
Domain theory of magnetism — Introduced in Class 9
